Patent US8635366B2 was born. Fifteen years and 64 forward citati
articles.content: In 2009 most location patents were about GPS. We took a different route: use the badge-swipe data enterprises already had, infer where someone probably is, and route calls accordingly ‚Äî no tracking, no battery drain, no extra hardware. Patent US8635366B2 was born. Fifteen years and 64 forward citations later (including Cisco, Microsoft, Avaya, RingCentral, Mitel), it feels worth revisiting. articles.content: It‚Äôs long been known that X (and Twitter before it) is a major venue for foreign influence campaigns to meddle in American politics. Much of the focus has been on Russian troll farms , which the US government has targeted on several occasions . But the launch of X‚Äôs About This Account feature may have revealed the scope and geographical breadth of its foreign troll problem. Almost immediately after the feature launched, people started noticing that many rage-bait accounts focused on US politics

articles.content: ‚Äú√à bravo, ma non si impegna.‚Äù ( ‚Äú He is very smart, but if he put in more effort, he could achieve so much more. ‚Äù ) This sentence followed me for my entire childhood. articles.title: DOGE is no more, and in its wake, only chaos

articles.content: In April, Elon Musk began backing away from his role as head of DOGE. By June, he was more or less fully gone from DC . In his wake, he left a power vacuum and significant ill will that has apparently led to the dissolution of DOGE eight months before its charter expires. To call Musk‚Äôs DC tenure contentious would be an understatement. As a man accustomed to getting what he wants and functioning as a powerful executive, he swept through Washington with a figurative chainsaw, slashing budgets, fi

articles.title: This hacker conference installed a literal antivirus monitoring system
articles.description: Organizers had a way for attendees to track CO 2 levels throughout the venue‚Äîeven before they arrived.
articles.content: Hacker conferences‚Äîlike all conventions‚Äîare notorious for giving attendees a parting gift of mystery illness. To combat ‚Äúcon crud,‚Äù New Zealand‚Äôs premier hacker conference, Kawaiicon, quietly launched a real-time, room-by-room carbon dioxide monitoring system for attendees. To get the system up and running, event organizers installed DIY CO 2 monitors throughout the Michael Fowler Centre venue before conference doors opened on November 6.
